details: Viral or bacterial infection causing inflammation in the digestive system, leading to vomiting, cramps, and potential dehydration resulting in hypotension.}, {diagnosis: Food Poisoning
details: Ingestion of contaminated food with bacteria or toxins, often leading to severe vomiting, cramps, and potential dehydration causing hypotension.}, {diagnosis: Intestinal Obstruction
details: Blockage in the small or large intestine, preventing passage of food and leading to vomiting, cramping, and potential complications like hypotension.}, {diagnosis: Dehydration
details: Excessive loss of fluids, often due to vomiting, leading to electrolyte imbalance, hypotension, and potential complications like wheezing.}, {diagnosis: Appendicitis
details: Inflammation of the appendix, causing severe abdominal pain that may radiate, often accompanied by vomiting and potential complications leading to hypotension.}, {diagnosis: Pancreatitis
details: Inflammation of the pancreas, causing intense abdominal pain, vomiting, and potential complications like fluid accumulation leading to hypotension.}, {diagnosis: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
details: A serious complication of diabetes, leading to high blood sugar, vomiting, abdominal pain, and potential respiratory distress causing wheezing.}, {diagnosis: Severe Allergy (Anaphylaxis)
details: A life-threatening allergic reaction, causing a range of symptoms like vomiting, cramps, hypotension due to airway constriction, and wheezing.}, {diagnosis: Aspirin Poisoning

details: Toxicity from aspirin overdose, leading to symptoms like vomiting, abdominal pain, and potential complications like respiratory problems causing wheezing.}, {diagnosis: Organophosphate Poisoning
details: Exposure to organophosphate insecticides, leading to a range of symptoms including vomiting, cramps, hypotension, and potential respiratory failure causing wheezing.}
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohns disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohns disease, Ulcerative colitis)

explanation: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause airway compromise (laryngeal edema, wheezing), skin reactions (pruritis), and gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting). Conjunctival injections can also occur.}, {diagnosis: Angioedema

explanation: Swelling beneath the skin, often affecting the face (including the larynx), tongue, and throat. It can cause airway obstruction (laryngeal edema, wheezing) and may be accompanied by itching (pruritis). Vomiting and conjunctival injections can occur in some cases.}, {diagnosis: Drug allergy
explanation: An allergic reaction to a medication, which can manifest with symptoms like laryngeal edema, wheezing, pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections.}, {diagnosis: Food allergy
explanation: An allergic reaction to a specific food, potentially leading to laryngeal edema, wheezing, pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections.}, {diagnosis: Insect sting allergy
explanation: An allergic reaction to an insect sting (e.g., bee, wasp), which can cause laryngeal edema, wheezing, pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections.}, {diagnosis: Viral infection

explanation: Some viral infections can cause respiratory symptoms like laryngeal edema and wheezing, as well as gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting) and conjunctivitis (conjunctival injections). Pruritis may occur in some cases.}, {diagnosis: Mastocytosis

explanation: A rare disorder characterized by an excess of mast cells (immune cells) in the body. It can cause a range of symptoms, including laryngeal edema, wheezing, pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections.}, {diagnosis: Hereditary angioedema

explanation: A genetic condition that causes recurrent episodes of angioedema, potentially affecting the larynx (laryngeal edema, wheezing). Pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections may occur.}, {diagnosis: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

explanation: An autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs. In rare cases, it can cause laryngeal edema, wheezing, pruritis, vomiting, and conjunctival injections.}, {diagnosis: Churg-Strauss syndrome

explanation: A rare autoimmune disorder that affects small and medium-sized blood vessels. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including respiratory problems (laryngeal edema, wheezing), skin involvement (pruritis), gastrointestinal issues (vomiting), and eye inflammation (conjunctival injections).}
Overlap syndrome (e.g., lupus and Sjögrens syndrome)
